{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3683071,"name":"Foster","username":"Foster","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/aca169/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-17T21:51:23.593Z","cooked":"

Help me with the right term. Crown gears are where the teeth stick up like little points from the face. Spur gears have the teeth on the outer edge.

In the picture below the white gear is what I’m asking about . You can see the blue gears on the spur part of the gear and the green gear riding on the points of the crown gear.

So the correct name for this Frankenstein gear is a … ? I’ve seen them on a few teams swerve drives.

image314×133 44.3 KB

Thanks!

Crown gear, cage gear, or lantern gear are all somewhat overlapping terms for that type of gear.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-17T22:01:04.207Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":658,"readers_count":657,"score":186.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504372,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears","display_username":"Zach Hoegberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20681,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"112 Drive Coach | 111&112 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears/504372/2","custom_user_title":"112 Drive Coach | 111&112 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683113,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-17T23:16:41.609Z","cooked":"

I would characterize this as a crown gear and a spur gear that share a tooth pitch (allowing for this beautiful packaging). At least in the crown gears I am aware of (I am not an engineer, at least by education) the tooth profile of the crown is not just points, they have a face width. I see no bevel “face” at an angle, it all seems to be an orthogonal arrangement, crown on top, spur on the edge, sharing the same pitch.

The cool part is how it is all jammed close together.

As an aside: I don’t follow VEX, is differential swerve common. This very much appears to be a differential swerve module using “crown gears”. (971 differential swerve to be precise)

If you wanna come up with a funny name like clown gear or jaw gear to use as a joke for these I think it’s a bit of good fun.

s-l400400×400 12.9 KB

In Lego terms this is a crown gear, like most good Lego piece names it is named after what it looks like.

Skyehawk:

I would characterize this as a crown gear and a spur gear that share a tooth pitch (allowing for this beautiful packaging).

Good way to describe it, thanks.

Still looking for a shorter name that they are called.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T01:38:48.527Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":325,"readers_count":324,"score":75.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504372,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears","display_username":"Foster","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8618,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"VEX in Delmarva - Chief Roboteer STEMRobotics"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears/504372/5","custom_user_title":"VEX in Delmarva - Chief Roboteer STEMRobotics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683594,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T10:07:17.043Z","cooked":"

“Crown and Pinion(Spur) bevel gearbox” is about the best I can come up with. It’s a gearbox, it describes both gear types needed and ‘bevel’ implies how they meet at a 90° angle like other beveled spur gears do.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T10:09:37.479Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":249,"readers_count":248,"score":109.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504372,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":8618,"username":"Foster","name":"Foster","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/aca169/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears/504372/6","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683610,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T11:33:19.469Z","cooked":"

These sorts of gears are really nice for toys because the can act as bevel gears, spur gears or both at the same time, but you’d basically never see something like this in any application that needs to hold much load or efficiency. To make the gears perform as well as normal gears you’d need to have a fully formed spur gear teeth and miter gear teeth. While you certainly could cut both types of teeth into the same chuck of metal, it would be a quite expensive and part that would basically be specific to a single gearbox. Proper miter gears are matched sets that are defined by the face width, diameter, tooth count of both gears, and the angle between the axes.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T11:33:19.469Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":223,"readers_count":222,"score":109.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504372,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears/504372/7","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683675,"name":"Bailey","username":"bkahl","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bkahl/{size}/173222_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T14:14:24.154Z","cooked":"
Skyehawk:

I don’t follow VEX, is differential swerve common. This very much appears to be a differential swerve module using “crown gears”.

Not really -

My hands are actually the ones in that picture. Foster is cross-posting a question he asked on VEX Forum.

I had posted about a VEX IQ replica of FRC 148’s 2023 robot, and it uses some custom differential swerve modules, that a former fellow VEX employee and 148 mentor & I worked on for a bit about 2 years ago. Foster wanted to see more, so I posted a breakdown of the modules, and sent a video of this module, which was a different revision, as it demonstrated the differential part of the mechanism a bit easier. The Spur/Crown compound gears intrigued him, but TBH I didn’t know if they had a special name.

Unfortunately, the robot is still incomplete. I need to get around to finishing the intake one of these days. Everything else works, though - Differential swerve, 2-Stage Cascading Elevator, Elevator Pivot/Rotation, Power is sent up the robot to the intake motor, it just doesn’t have anything to spin yet.

Some pictures:

image1920×2560 588 KB

image490×641 70.7 KB

This second picture is the module on the robot. Picture Foster sent is of a different module that packages differently, but is a bit easier to understand.

Thread for reference, if anyone is interested

Patrick3357:

These sorts of gears are really nice for toys because the can act as bevel gears, spur gears or both at the same time, but you’d basically never see something like this in any application that needs to hold much load or efficiency.

These used to be EVERYWHERE in HEXBUGs.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T14:20:10.295Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":158,"readers_count":157,"score":61.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504372,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears","display_username":"Bailey","primary_group_name":"VEX","flair_name":"VEX","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/f/b/fbf8d6ace815b6285a91d1dedb54a63db4c60840.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":56,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20709,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"VEX Robotics | 148 Mentor | Formerly 195&125"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears/504372/9","custom_user_title":"VEX Robotics | 148 Mentor | Formerly 195&125","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683696,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T14:36:00.570Z","cooked":"

A contrate gear is one where the teeth are on the face, but (key bit) it meshes with a normal spur gear. There is a pitch plane, rather than conical pitch surfaces seen in a bevel gear. Heres a good picture:

17528492912478396960123331559557200×160 5.37 KB

And more looking… crown gear is the other word for this.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T14:40:24.173Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":142,"readers_count":141,"score":88.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504372,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52870,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Amateur Historian?"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears/504372/11","custom_user_title":"Amateur Historian?","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3683766,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T15:01:30.970Z","cooked":"

Ah, yes, the @nuclearnerd design! (At least that’s where I remember seeing it first). Or at least very close to the power paths.

Your daily dose of ridiculousness - 775 pro differential swerve Technical Discussion
I drew this up on the weekend to see if I could. I was inspired by the awesome swerve posted here: pic: Swerve Module, 2910 MK1 - CD-Media: Photos - Chief Delphi? and I remembered the differential swerve idea posted here: Pic: 4143 differential swerve concept - CD-Media: Photos - Chief Delphi. My goal was to come up with a compact swerve module, run by two 775 pros, which handled both power and steering (via differential speed). Here’s the (incomplete) result. The advantage is that, e…

Thanks @Skyehawk for digging into the 2017’s to pull out the @nuclearnerd design.

Back in the dawn of my robotics path I was a member of Team 1640 Sab-bot-age and they had a thing for swerve. So I’ve been interested in swerve designs. I’ve been on the VEX path and have built versions in the V5 line. VEXIQ is more of a challenge and I was pretty excited when @bkahl posted pictures from a VEXIQ robot that had a swerve drive.

It does look like it was a take off from Brendan’s design. They kind of solved the drive to steer ratio issue by using the bevel gears and a very small wheel.

But Bailey threw in a video that I posted the screen capture from. The white gears were 3D printed and is an awesome hack of the idea. In the VEX world, the roboteers re-name “everything” (ie screws => twisty holders) and it’s often hard to figure out what they are talking about. I was pretty sure that nobody on the VEX forum would have any idea what the proper name for the white gear would be. But I figured the CD crew would know.

At this time the best name I’ve got is “crowned pinion gear”, and doing a google search got me this 02-96200P2 Crowned Gear With Pinion - OWI Inc. dba: Robotikits™ Direct but the crown teeth are going in towards the pinion, not out. But I’ve always assumed that pinion gears have a slant to the teeth, where spur gears do not.

I’d like to go with crowned spur gear, but that has a specific meaning that there is a crown or outward bulge on the spur gear teeth to help with meshing them.

Thanks for all of the posts, I appreciate the help

Crowning of gear teeth is adding just a whiff of bulge to the tooth face. This ensures the contact patch is away from the edges even with a little misalignment. A tool to reduce stress concentration.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-07-18T17:34:47.623Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":86,"readers_count":85,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504372,"topic_slug":"what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-is-the-name-of-the-white-gears/504372/14","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3684526,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-19T02:32:26.370Z","cooked":"

A pinion typically just means a small gear that meshes with a much larger gear or a rack. It is usually the drive gear not the driven.

Spur gear just means a standard straight cut gear with a simple extruded profile designed to mesh with other spur gears with particular axes of rotation. They are the simplest, easiest to manufacture gears so they are most common, but with the proliferation and improvement in 3d printing and 4-axis milling, helical and herringbone bone gears are much more accessible and can replace spur gears improving efficiency and, in the case of herringbone, providing axial alignment between gears. Spur gears can be internal or external.
